titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edward W. Sites Papers, 1958-2019 UA.90.F109
titlestmt.author: Edward Sites

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-17 10:38:57 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Edward Sites Ph.D. was a social worker and faculty member of the University of Pittsburgh's School of Social Work from 1966 until becoming professor emeritus in 2006. This collection documents the history of the School of Social Work during Sites' career through reports, memoranda, publications, and other records.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Edward Sites, Ph.D. is a social worker and emeritus faculty member of the University of Pittsburgh.

Sites began his academic career at the University of Pittsburgh's School of Social Work in 1966. During his time on the faculty, he served as the school's Director of Admission and Financial Aid; Chair of the Children and Youth Concentration; Coordinator of the Joint Master of Social Work/Master of Divinity degree program with the Pittsburgh Theological Seminary; Coordinator of the Home School Visitor Program; a member of the Doctoral faculty; and the founding Principal Investigator of the Pennsylvania Child Welfare Education and Research Programs. Sites taught numerous subjects, specifically child welfare policy and grant proposal writing. In 2006, he was named a professor emeritus. Outside the classroom, Sites serves as the Facilitator of Allegheny County's Act 33 Child Fatality/Near Fatality Review Team and works on special projects with the School of Social Work.

Sites earned a bachelor's degree from Gettysburg College in 1962 and a Master's in Social Work from the University of Pittsburgh in 1964. Before joining the University of Pittsburgh faculty, he was a social worker with the Pennsylvania Department of Public Welfare's Office for Children and Youth from 1962 to 1966 and a Sociology instructor at Wilson College from 1965 to 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Edward Sites Papers contain the collected works and papers of Professor Sites. The collection spans from 1958 to 2019 and contains records pertaining to the School of Social Work at the University of Pittsburgh. Topics covered in this collection include Administration for Children Youth and Families; Child Development/Child Care; Children and Youth Cluster; Long Range Planning; Promotion and Tenure Committee; and Statistics on the School of Social Work, among others. It also includes School of Social Work accreditation reports to the Council on Social Work Education and faculty meeting minutes. Audiovisual recordings of lectures, interviews, and trainings on numerous subjects are located at the end of the collection.

Material specific to Sites' career include his incoming and outgoing professional correspondence and memoranda pertaining to the administration of the School of Social Work and University of Pittsburgh, as well as other organizations affiliated with Sites such as the Pennsylvania Rehabilitation Center. Also included are administrative files and reports for many of Sites' projects including "Steeltown Fathers: Rearing Children in an Era of Industrial Decline" and a collaboration with the Pittsburgh AIDS Taskforce to help train public school staff and others who were likely to work closely with youth at a high risk of exposure to AIDS.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edward W. Sites Papers, 1958-2019, UA.90.F109, University Archives, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Edward Sites from 2017 to 2019.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Edward Sites in 2006, 2008 and 2019.
